JOHNNY GREEN: And ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of our absent colleague and devoted friend, Saul Chaplin, great thanks from all of us.

name: Mancini, Henry
Mercer, Johnny
speeches.speech: HENRY MANCINI: I've said my bit, go ahead.  JOHNNY MERCER: I'd like to say that I'm very proud that you like our song. I'd like to thank you, Audrey. Thank you, Andy. And martinis for everybody.  HENRY MANCINI: Thank you.

name: Teresak, Vlado
speeches.speech: VLADO TERESAK: On behalf of Zagreb Film and Herts-Lion I would like to thank the members of Academy for this award. Thank you.

name: Gamble, Frederick H.
speeches.speech: FREDERICK H. GAMBLE: Ladies and gentlemen, it is not very often that somebody in my profession is given an Academy Award. And I must confess that I had nothing whatever to do with making the film but I'm very proud and happy to accept it on behalf of the British makers and I will see that it is sent to them as quickly as possible. Thank you very much.

name: Sawyer, Gordon E.
Hynes, Fred
speeches.speech: FRED HYNES: I want to thank all the members of the Academy and everyone who made this possible, especially Murray Spivack, Glenn Rominger and Joe Kane. Thank you very much.  GORDON E. SAWYER: On behalf of the Samuel Goldwyn Sound Department, and especially Fred Lau and Vinton Vernon, I wish to thank the Academy. Thank you very much.

name: Morduch, Joan
Warrington, Bill
speeches.speech: JOAN MORDUCH: On behalf of Chris Greenham I'd like to thank everybody so much for this.  BILL WARRINGTON: To the members of the Academy, I can't honestly...I'm so terribly excited, except thank you very much. Thank you very much.

name: Mann, Abby
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: ABBY MANN: A few years ago I retired to a room on 58th Street in New York, and I retired there with some legal records of the Third Reich. And I went there because I believe that a writer who's worth his salt at all has an obligation not only to entertain but to comment on the world in which he lives. Not only to comment, maybe, but to maybe have a shot at reshaping that world. It's a long way from that room to this hall and I couldn't accept this without, without mentioning a couple of allies I'd picked up on the way. One, of course, is my brilliant mentor, Stanley Kramer; a man of courage, talent, and a man of his word. And probably the most gifted cast that a writer ever had in on a picture, to say thanks to you, Spence, Burt, Judy, Dick, Marlene, Max. I tell you, I consider this from the Academy [holds up his Oscar] to be a trust. And I promise you this, I won't abuse it.

name: Inge, William
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: WILLIAM INGE: You never know how you're going to feel about this sort of thing until it happens. It's very moving. I'm very grateful to Elia Kazan, to a marvelous cast and marvelous crew. Thank you.

name: Seaton, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE SEATON: I was privileged to know and work with the man for whom this award was named. I had a tremendous admiration and respect for him and for his code of human behavior which he lived by. I'm also fortunate to know the past recipients of this award: Mr. Y. Frank Freeman, Mr. Samuel Goldwyn, Mr. Sol Lesser and Mr. Bob Hope. Like Jean Hersholt they have given so much of themselves over the years to so many people. When one's own contributions are put alongside of theirs, no matter how puny they might be, it's a tremendous tribute. I am deeply grateful to the members of the Board of Governors of the Academy for thinking that I qualify as a freshman to this honored society. I promise I shall do everything I can to continue to do what I can so that maybe one day I will feel that I have honestly earned this. Thank you very much.

name: Metzler, Fred L.
speeches.speech: FRED L. METZLER: Thank you, Mr. President. I believe so deeply in the Academy that I consider it a privilege to work for its aims and for its principals. The Academy is a great institution and to receive this award is a great honor indeed. I'm very grateful, and my sincere thanks to you all.

name: Robbins, Jerome
speeches.speech: JEROME ROBBINS: I am very deeply grateful to the Academy for this honor and I'd like to share it with all those that worked so very hard both in front of the camera and behind the camera. Thank you.

name: Hendricks, William L.
speeches.speech: WILLIAM L. HENDRICKS: For the Secretary of the Navy, for the Commandant of the Marine Corps, for our marines and sailors everywhere, for all those who contributed to the making of 'A Force in Readiness,' and for myself, thank you.

name: Kramer, Stanley
speeches.speech: STANLEY KRAMER: Unfortunately, I did not know Irving Thalberg. However, it is true, believe me, that his mother and my grandmother were bridge partners. Whatever their mutual Valhalla today I think I would like it most, really like it most if I thought that Irving Thalberg believed that I might reasonably have deserved this award. My grandmother believes it, believe me. Thank you.

name: Spiegel, Sam
speeches.speech: SAM SPIEGEL: Ladies and gentlemen, there is no magic formula for creating good pictures. They are made with the serious, concerted hard work by everyone connected in the making of them: the writer, the director, the technicians, actors, thousands of employees of the picture during the making of it. In their behalf, in behalf of all of those who sweated months in the desert to create this picture, I deeply, sincerely thank the voters of the Academy and proudly accept this honor in their behalf, proudly and humbly. Thank you very much.

name: Peck, Gregory
speeches.speech: GREGORY PECK: Thank you, fellow Academy members. Thank you, Harper Lee, Alan Pakula, Robert Mulligan, Russ Harlan, all of my good friends and associates at the studio. Thank you, members of the press who cover the local scene, critics, columnists across the country who approved of my work and said so. And I want to thank my family, my good, close friends, who have lent me inspiration and moral support and affection. Thank you very much.

name: Begley, Ed
speeches.speech: ED BEGLEY: I'm not Ed Begley. I've come a long way from Hartford, Connecticut. I want to thank Pandro Berman first because without him I wouldn't be in the picture. But I owe a great, great deal of thanks to Richard Brooks. A man for whom I had worked before; a fine director. But most of all, and this is from the heart, my agent George Morris. Really and truly this man had faith in me that I didn't have myself. I never dreamed I would get that part, but he had faith in me and he kept after it and I got it. Thank you very, very much.

name: Crawford, Joan
speeches.speech: JOAN CRAWFORD: Miss Bancroft said, here's my little speech, dear Joan. Quote: 'There are three reasons why I deserve this award: Arthur Penn, Bill Gibson, Fred Coe.' Unquote. Thank you.

name: Duke, Patty
speeches.speech: PATTY DUKE: Thank you.

name: Lean, David
speeches.speech: DAVID LEAN: This limey is deeply touched and greatly honored. Thank you.

name: Golitzen, Alexander
Bumstead, Henry
Emert, Oliver
speeches.speech: ALEXANDER GOLITZEN: From our other associates and the craftsmen that worked with us in Hollywood, thank you very much.  HENRY BUMSTEAD: Thank you very much.  OLIVER EMERT: Thanks everyone.

name: Jeffreys, Anne
Sterling, Robert
speeches.speech: ROBERT STERLING: This is indeed a joyous night for everyone connected with 'Lawrence of Arabia.'  ANNE JEFFREYS: And it's a great honor for us to be able to accept these awards for Mr. Box and Mr. Stoll. Thank you so much.

name: Metzler, Fred L.
speeches.speech: FRED L. METZLER: I'm honored to accept the awards for the three cameramen of 'The Longest Day' who could not be here tonight. I'm sure they will feel grateful to all who made this possible. Thank you.

name: Lynley, Carol
speeches.speech: CAROL LYNLEY: On behalf of Mr. Young and Columbia I want to thank you very much for this. It's very richly deserved. Thank you.

name: Koch, Norma
speeches.film: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?
speeches.speech: NORMA KOCH: My deepest appreciation to Robert Aldrich and all the 'Baby Jane's' wherever you are.

name: Wills, Mary
speeches.film: The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm
speeches.speech: MARY WILLS: Thank you very much.

name: Stoumen, Louis Clyde
speeches.speech: LOUIS CLYDE STOUMEN: My heartfelt thanks to you members of the Academy. Also, thanks from my associates in the production of 'Black Fox': Mr. Jack Le Vien, Mr. Don Devlin, Mr. Skip Steloff, and above all, our star, Miss Marlene Dietrich.

name: Howells, Jack
speeches.speech: JACK HOWELLS: I'd just like to say I think there's one man, I'd like, would be very proud to be here tonight, a man who loved the movies very dearly, as I know him—I knew him personally, and that's Dylan Thomas himself. Anyway, I can't speak for Dylan but I personally am more proud than I can say. Thank you all very, very much.

name: Stack, Robert
speeches.speech: ROBERT STACK: The task of putting together a motion picture the size of 'Lawrence of Arabia' must be a monumental one. Well, Anne Coates sure put it together to the tune of ten nominations, two awards so far, and the night is young. I know how much she wishes she could be here to thank you in person. Thank you.

name: Bourguignon, Serge
speeches.speech: SERGE BOURGUIGNON: Well, I must say I'm very proud, especially on behalf of my crew; my actors Hardy Krüger, Nicole Courcel, little Patricia Gozzi; and my producers, Mr. Romain Pinès and and his partners. And well, what else could I say? Thank you very, very much; and I say merci beaucoup. Oh yes, one more thing. Maybe the next title of my film will be 'Monday and Oscar' after 'Sundays and Cybele.' Thank you.

name: Stoloff, Morris
speeches.speech: MORRIS STOLOFF: I'm not Maurice Jarre; I was coordinator for the music of 'Lawrence of Arabia.' But in his absence I would like to thank the Motion Picture Academy, Columbia Pictures, Mr. Sam Spiegel, David Lean for this honor. I'm sure he'd be very happy and very grateful. Thank you very much.

name: Heindorf, Ray
speeches.speech: RAY HEINDORF: Thank you very much. And thank you, Meredith.

name: Mancini, Henry
Mercer, Johnny
speeches.speech: JOHNNY MERCER: Ladies and gentlemen, of course Mr. Dowson gave me a beautiful title and Mr. Mancini gave me a beautiful tune, but I'm grateful anyway. Thank you very much.  HENRY MANCINI: I'd like to thank the Academy; my old friend Blake Edwards; my new friend Martin Manulis, the producer; and my huckleberry friend, Johnny Mercer. Thank you.

name: Hubley, John
speeches.speech: JOHN HUBLEY: Thank you very much, everyone. And I'd like to express thanks, too, to the people who worked on the picture. The animators: Bill Littlejohn, Gary Mooney. The voices: George Mathews, Dizzy Gillespie. And Pat Byron, and our producer Tom Brandt*. Thank you.

name: Roth, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE ROTH: Thank you very much. It is with great thanks that I accept these for the producers Pierre Etaix and J.C. Carrière. If they were here, and I'm sorry they couldn't be, I'm sure they would have said: À tous nos amis dans l'academie, merci beaucoup. Au revoir.

name: Wagner, Robert
speeches.speech: ROBERT WAGNER: On behalf of John Cox, Columbia Pictures, my friends David Lean and Sam Spiegel, I'm very proud and very pleased to accept this award.

name: Martin, Ivan
speeches.speech: IVAN MARTIN: On behalf of Mr. Robert MacDonald and Mr. Maumont, my thanks and appreciation to the Academy. Thank you.

name: Pakula, Alan J.
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: ALAN J. PAKULA: For Horton Foote I'd like to express deep gratitude to the members of the Academy. And for all of us associated with 'To Kill a Mockingbird,' I would like to express our deep gratitude to Mr. Horton Foote. Thank you.

name: Germi, Pietro
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: PIETRO GERMI: I was absolutely sure not to have anything, so surprise and joy and, thank you.

name: Broidy, Steve
speeches.speech: STEVE BROIDY: It is with deep humility that I accept the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award. To join the previous recipients of this award is both stimulating and rewarding. Being a part of an industry that gives so much of its time, talent and resources for the good of its fellow man makes me feel very proud and I hope to be able to continue in this tradition. Thank you.

name: Poitier, Sidney
speeches.speech: SIDNEY POITIER: Because it is a long journey to this moment I am naturally indebted to countless numbers of people, principally among whom are Ralph Nelson, James Poe, William Barrett, Martin Baum, and of course the members of the Academy. For all of them, all I can say is a very special thank you.

name: Spiegel, Sam
speeches.speech: SAM SPIEGEL: One of the advantages of getting the Irving Thalberg Award is that it's announced a few days before the Academy evening and it gives one an opportunity to prepare, laboriously prepare, a speech. And then one faces the community of friends and co-workers with whom one spent the major part of one's life and the temptation is to say nothing else, scrap the prepared speech and just say simply: I'm proud to be receiving this award; I'm delighted that I have earned it in this community; and I'm humbly confident that this community will exert its influence, everlasting influence and ever present influence, on every corner of the world where motion pictures are made. Thank you.

name: Fellini, Federico
speeches.speech: FEDERICO FELLINI: I am particularly happy to receive this fabulous award because it comes to me on the eve of my next picture, and I don't think that a director about to start his new job could wish for anything more stimulating and auspicious as this. I want you all to accept my deepest and most humble thanks. Arrivederci e buona fortuna.

name: De Wilde, Brandon
speeches.speech: BRANDON DE WILDE: Mr. Douglas is in Spain and he wished me to thank the members of the Academy and his fellow actors and the entire group that was on 'Hud' for this honor. Thank you.

name: Annabella
speeches.speech: ANNABELLA: Pat has a most wonderful excuse for not being with you tonight. You know she is expecting her first—fourth—child in London. But I know she's very happy, very proud, very grateful. She thank you all, all her thanks. And a very special one from Martin Ritt and for Paul Newman. Thank you all for her.

name: Ustinov, Peter
speeches.speech: PETER USTINOV: May I, on behalf of a most distinguished, most deserving, and most funny friend, say thank you very much indeed.

name: Callahan, Gene
speeches.speech: GENE CALLAHAN: Thank you all very much.

name: Smith, Jack Martin
speeches.speech: JACK MARTIN SMITH: Ladies and gentlemen, not all of us are here. The rest of our team is in Italy, all five of them. And we want to extend to the Academy a big thank you from them with us, especially John DeCuir, our production designer, and Hilyard Brown, the admiral of our fleet. Thank you so much.

name: Howe, James Wong
speeches.speech: JAMES WONG HOWE: My throat's very dry. I got butterflies. But I want to thank Mr. Ritt for giving me the opportunity to photograph 'Hud,' a wonderful crew from Paramount Studios, and all the members of the Motion Picture Academy. Thank you.

name: Shamroy, Leon
speeches.speech: LEON SHAMROY: Before I accept this award I must pay homage to my American crew and my Italian crew who were so dedicated to the completion of this picture. Thank you very much.

name: Gherardi, Piero
speeches.speech: PIERO GHERARDI: Thank you, America.

name: Renie
speeches.speech: RENIE: On behalf of Miss Sharaff and Mr. Novarese, thank you. For myself, I am truly grateful.

name: Evans, Edith
speeches.speech: DAME EDITH EVANS: I'm so happy to take this back for Tony. It was a very richly deserved award, I think, and we're very grateful indeed to you for giving it to him. Thank you very much indeed.

name: Hughes, Robert
speeches.film: Robert Frost: A Lover's Quarrel with the World
speeches.speech: ROBERT HUGHES: On behalf of Charlotte Zwerin and everyone else who made this picture, I'm so pleased I'm speechless. Most important, it's yet another honor for our star, Robert Frost.

name: Auerbach, Josef
speeches.speech: JOSEF AUERBACH: On behalf of Schiffrin and all the others, thank you very much for the honor.

name: Kress, Harold F.
speeches.speech: HAROLD F. KRESS: The words 'thank you' can hardly express my feelings at this moment. But I do want to express my gratitude to all the young men and the woman that helped me very much on this picture. And to stand here and accept this from such a fine, fine actor is a great privilege and a great honor. Thank you.

name: Bernstein, Elmer
speeches.speech: ELMER BERNSTEIN: It is my very great pleasure to join my colleague John Addison in thanking you very much for honoring his music for 'Tom Jones.' Thank you very much.

name: Previn, Andre
speeches.speech: ANDRE PREVIN: It's always a great pleasure to work for Mr. Wilder and Mr. Diamond, and I thank them. I'm very grateful to the orchestra who played my score so beautifully. And most of all, thank you.

name: Van Heusen, James
Cahn, Laurie
speeches.speech: LAURIE CAHN: For my father Mr. Cahn, I thank you.  JAMES VAN HEUSEN: I'd like to express my thanks, along with the thanks of my father, for this wonderful honor. I'm deeply grateful to the members of the Academy. Thank you very much.

name: Picker, David V.
speeches.speech: DAVID V. PICKER: If Tony were here he'd undoubtedly say that your granting this award to him was super. Tony couldn't be here tonight, but on behalf of Tony and on behalf of all of his associates at Woodfall Films, and on behalf of myself and my associates at United Artists, we are most grateful, most appreciative. My heart is in my throat. Thank you so much.

name: Pintoff, Ernest
speeches.speech: ERNEST PINTOFF: I'm very grateful. I'd like to thank my collaborator, the wonderful and talented Mel Brooks. I'd like to thank Arnold Stone, Bob Heath and Columbia Pictures. Thank you.

name: Lord, Jack
speeches.film: An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge
speeches.speech: JACK LORD: Mr. Paul de Roubaix and Marcel Ichac, who are in Paris, have asked me to express their deepest gratitude to the members of the Academy for this great honor. Thank you.

name: Milton, Franklin E.
speeches.speech: FRANKLIN E. MILTON: Thanks to you all from the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Sound Department.

name: Elliott, Walter G.
speeches.film: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
speeches.speech: WALTER G. ELLIOTT: From all of us in the 'Mad, Mad, Mad World' thank you very, very much.

name: Kosa, Emil, Jr.
speeches.speech: EMIL KOSA, JR.: Thank you very much. I wish I could take the lady [presenter Angie Dickinson] home with me instead of this little Oscar.

name: Goff, Ivan
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: IVAN GOFF: On behalf of John Osborne, thank you very much.

name: Webb, James R.
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: JAMES R. WEBB: It took me about as long to win this as it did to win the West. I would like to thank a great producer, three great directors, a hatful of superb performers, and a screenwriter named John Gay who rode to the rescue in many a moment of dire peril. Thank you so much.

name: Harrison, Rex
speeches.speech: REX HARRISON: Well, this is a very exciting evening for me and I feel in a way that I should split it in half [kisses Hepburn] between us.  AUDREY HEPBURN: You deserve it all.  REX HARRISON: I would like to thank everybody that had anything to do with the making of 'My Fair Lady.' It was a wonderful experience and I must thank George for being so marvelous with us, and Jack, and everybody else that's connected with it. And deep love to, well [looking at Hepburn], to fair ladies, I think.

name: Winters, Jonathan
speeches.speech: JONATHAN WINTERS: I don't know whether Peter expected this, I certainly didn't. Otherwise I would have been sure to wear black socks. But I'll make this very brief. I'm more excited than if Peter were here himself. He's in England. I'm pretty sure in Europe. Obviously he isn't here; but if he were here, he, I'm sure, would be almost as speechless as me. That's about it. Thank you so much on behalf of the Academy, the industry and everything. I hope that covers everybody. Thank you.

name: Andrews, Julie
speeches.speech: JULIE ANDREWS: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Oh, this is lovely. I know you Americans are famous for your hospitality but this is really ridiculous. I have so many thank yous. I only know where to start and that's with Mr. Walt Disney, and naturally he has the largest thank you of all. I wouldn't know where to stop. I would somehow like to try and convey my really deep gratitude and, and well, gratefulness – well I just said that, hadn't I? – for being made to feel so really welcome in this country. Thank you very much indeed.

name: Kedrova, Lila
speeches.speech: LILA KEDROVA: Do you know, really I am so surprised that I can't, I don't know what... I have to say, I think that I will say that, thank you to this marvelous people of [unintelligible] Academy Awards. And thank you, thank you so much my dear, dear Michael Cacoyannis. Because it was your fault, it was not mine. I will never forget it. Never.

name: Fotopoulos, Vassilis
speeches.speech: VASSILIS FOTOPOULOS: Is a great honor for me and for my country. Is very nice. Is very nice and very sweet. I thank you the awards of the Academy of the [unintelligible] honor. Believe me, it's something I never imagined from where I come [unintelligible].

name: Allen, Gene
Hopkins, George James
speeches.speech: GENE ALLEN: So many people to thank, but we want to say to Miss Audrey Hepburn that she lights our sets up so we really can win these awards. Thank you.  GEORGE JAMES HOPKINS: Thank you very much.

name: Dahl, Arlene
speeches.speech: ARLENE DAHL: [Holding the Oscar statuette.] Oh, he's so beautiful. Isn't he beautiful? Well, I just want to thank you [looks around the stage]...did somebody drop something? I just want to thank all of you, the Board of Directors and the Academy for making this possible for Mr. Lassally. I know how thrilled he must be. His beautiful camerawork contributed greatly to the brilliance of 'Zorba the Greek.' Thank you so much for him.

name: Stradling, Harry
speeches.speech: HARRY STRADLING: I'd like to thank Jack Warner, George Cukor for giving me the opportunity to photograph this film. A special thanks to Miss Audrey Hepburn for her appreciation. And many, many thanks to my crew. Thank you.

name: Jeakins, Dorothy
speeches.speech: DOROTHY JEAKINS: Thank you many people for many years work. I'm very grateful.

name: Cooper, Gladys
speeches.speech: GLADYS COOPER: Oh, on behalf of Cecil Beaton – he's missed such a night – I do accept this with the greatest of pleasure. Oh, how lovely. Thank you.

name: Cukor, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE CUKOR: I'm very grateful and very happy and very lucky. I had wonderful material to work with. I daren't name all the people that helped. I want to thank Mr. Jack Warner, who gave every support, every encouragement. Wonderful artists to work with. I must make a deep bow to Mr. Rex Harrison and to adorable Audrey Hepburn. I thank everybody and I thank you.

name: Cord, Alex
speeches.speech: ALEX CORD: On behalf of Captain Cousteau and Columbia Pictures, it is indeed an honor to receive this award. I thank you very much.

name: Guggenheim, Charles
speeches.speech: CHARLES GUGGENHEIM: This great honor in great part belongs to George Stevens, Jr. and Carl Rowan of the United States Information Agency, who, by believing that motion pictures can be made with respect, have brought respect to the country that has produced them. Thank you very much.

name: Warburton, Cotton
speeches.speech: COTTON WARBURTON: All I can say is many, many thanks to all of you.

name: Levine, Joseph E.
speeches.speech: JOSEPH E. LEVINE: On behalf of Carlo Ponti, Vittorio De Sica, Marcello Mastroianni and Sophia Loren, thank you very much.

name: Sherman, Richard M.
Sherman, Robert B.
speeches.speech: ROBERT B. SHERMAN: We're so touched. We want to thank the inspiring Mr. Walt Disney, Mr. Bill Walsh...  RICHARD M. SHERMAN: Mr. Don DaGradi.  ROBERT B. SHERMAN: ...and...  RICHARD M. SHERMAN: Irwin Kostal, Bob Stevenson...  ROBERT B. SHERMAN: ...Julie Andrews...  RICHARD M. SHERMAN: ...our wonderful cast, Dick Van Dyke.  ROBERT B. SHERMAN: ...Dick Van Dyke.  RICHARD M. SHERMAN: There are so many people connected with 'Mary Poppins,' I'm sure we left quite a lot of them out.  ROBERT B. SHERMAN: We'll stay up all night thinking of them, too.  RICHARD M. SHERMAN: Thank you. Thank you, Academy, very much.

name: Sherman, Richard M.
Sherman, Robert B.
speeches.speech: ROBERT B. SHERMAN: Well, when there are no words to say, all you can say is [sings] supercalifragilistic...  RICHARD M. SHERMAN: [sings] ...expialidocious.  ROBERT B. SHERMAN: Thank you.

name: Previn, Andre
speeches.speech: ANDRE PREVIN: I'm very grateful to Alan Lerner and Fritz Loewe, and Mr. Cukor and Mr. Warner of course, and the many people who helped me. And I also want to pay tribute to the marvelous orchestra that played the score so beautifully. And of course, above all, I thank all of you.

name: Warner, Jack L.
speeches.speech: JACK L. WARNER: I am indeed gratified to be here tonight to accept this high award. And I want to thank first the Academy and its members for making it possible. Secondly, and equally I would say, I want to thank Mr. George Bernard Shaw for writing 'Pygmalion,' passing it into the hands of Alan Lerner. Then to the great composer, Frederick Loewe. Then to George Cukor, the director. His able associates and assistants, Cecil Beaton, Gene Allen, George Hopkins – I could name them for on and on but time is of the essence and I don't want to be cut off here I don't think. But I want to thank you very, very much, ladies and gentlemen, for presenting this for 'My Fair Lady.' It's something we will always be proud of, and I speak for those in the back lot, the front lot, upstairs, downstairs, everywhere. I know they thank you, and I thank you for them. Thank you.

name: DePatie, David H.
Freleng, Friz
speeches.speech: DAVID H. DePATIE: For ourselves and on behalf of our partner the Pink Panther, many, many thanks for this great honor.  FRIZ FRELENG: Please accept our thanks for your contribution... or your... I missed the word... [laughs]. Um... [looking over at DePatie:] what did I...  DAVID H. DePATIE: Just thanks [laughs].  FRIZ FRELENG: [Laughs] Thank you very much. I lost mine.

name: Schreiber, Edward
speeches.speech: EDWARD SCHREIBER: First, I'd like to tell this lady [presenter Merle Oberon] I've been in love with her for many years. Second, I didn't trip; my wife did not throw away the Dramamine tablets, we're through with them. And thank heavens for Pablo Casals at 88, the dearest man in the world. You have made me a very big man around my house. Thank you very much.

name: Groves, George R.
speeches.speech: GEORGE R. GROVES: On behalf of Warner Bros. Sound Department I thank you very much. I'd like to pay special tribute to Mr. Francis Scheid who did the production recording and to Mr. Murray Spivack who did such a fine job of recording the 'Fair Lady' music. Thank you very much.

name: Wanstall, Norman
speeches.speech: NORMAN WANSTALL: Ladies and gentlemen, it's very difficult to say thank you as sincerely as I'd like to now, but I'm a technician so maybe I can leave the eloquence to the artists that follow. But on behalf of the sound departments that I've worked with and my production company and myself, may I thank you all very sincerely for this tremendous honor. And once more may I thank you for the opportunity of coming to your wonderful country. I think for my wife and I this trip is going to be the greatest experience of our lives. Thank you very much indeed.

name: Ellenshaw, Peter
Lycett, Eustace
Luske, Hamilton
speeches.speech: PETER ELLENSHAW: I'd like to say thank you very much. It's been exciting. Thank you.  HAMILTON LUSKE: On behalf of Walt's fine animation department and especially Mac Stewart who had a great deal to do with winning this, thank you very much.  EUSTACE LYCETT: My sincere thanks to the Academy and all the people that worked with me on this picture, and especially the people in my department who worked very hard to make this thing possible. Thank you.

name: Anhalt, Edward
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: EDWARD ANHALT: I hope the television audience shares the feeling that comes from winning an award from a jury of one's fellow craftsmen. Thank you to Mr. Hal Wallis and thank you to the Academy.

name: Stone, Peter
Tarloff, Frank
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: PETER STONE: My deepest thanks to Cary Grant, who keeps winning these things for other people. Thank you.  FRANK TARLOFF: He just stole my whole speech.

name: Tuttle, William
speeches.speech: WILLIAM TUTTLE: My sincere thanks to the Board of Governors of the Academy, and to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and my wonderful staff in the makeup department and hairdressing department. And a very special thanks to Tony Randall, who brought the '7 Faces of Dr. Lao' to life. And most of all to a great pal of mine, Mr. George Pal.

name: Vlahos, Petro
Pohl, Wadsworth E.
Iwerks, Ub
speeches.categoryIndex: Scientific and Technical (Academy Award of Merit)
speeches.speech: PETRO VLAHOS: I'd like to express my thanks to the Academy Board of Governors. Thank you.  WADSWORTH E. POHL: Thank you very much.  UB IWERKS: Thank you most sincerely.

name: Jones, Chuck
Goldman, Les
speeches.speech: CHUCK JONES: A great deal has been said in favor of the idea that films are bigger than ever; we feel that occasionally some word can be said for films being smaller than ever. Norton Juster's book, 'The Dot and the Line,' we felt was a delightful, small book, and I'd like to particularly thank those people who, against all temptations, fought to keep it small: To Maurice Noble, to Eugene Poddany, and of all things to Robert Morley. Thank you very much.  LES GOLDMAN: It's a rare and privileged time when a major studio goes way out and backs a strange and wild entertainment film like 'The Dot and the Line.' And I want to thank the MGM management for being with us all the way, and, of course, all the members of the Academy. Thank you.

name: Christie, Julie
speeches.speech: JULIE CHRISTIE: I don't think I can say anything except to thank everyone concerned, and especially my darling John Schlesinger, for this wonderful honor. Thank you.

name: Marvin, Lee
speeches.speech: LEE MARVIN: Thank you. Thank you all very much. I don't want to take up too much of your time; there's too many people to correctly thank for my career. I think, though, that half of this belongs to a horse some place out in Nevada. Thank you.

name: Balsam, Martin
speeches.speech: MARTIN BALSAM: Thank you. I've just seen all those movies; I don't know what to say now. I'm elated. I'm delighted. I'm stunned. I want to thank UA. I want to thank Fred Coe. I want to thank Herb Gardner. And I want to thank all the people I've worked with and for. And the Academy. You've all made it possible. Thank you.

name: Winters, Shelley
speeches.speech: SHELLEY WINTERS: Thank you very much, members of the Academy, for giving this to me the second time in my life. I wish to thank very much my director, Mr. Guy Green, who truly understood the role I played better than I did. And I would like to especially thank Mr. Pandro Berman for not only making such a sensitive, beautiful picture about a subject of integration such as 'A Patch of Blue' is, but for making the picture a box-office success, which is very important for subjects like these. And I'd like to thank my agent again, Herb Brenner. Thank you.

name: Clatworthy, Robert
Kish, Joseph
speeches.speech: ROBERT CLATWORTHY: Thank you all very much. I'm deeply grateful to all of you whose people helped with the picture and, of course, Stanley Kramer. Thank you.  JOSEPH KISH: Thank you very much for the members of Academy. And thank you, Stanley, for the assignment.

name: Davis, George W.
speeches.speech: GEORGE W. DAVIS: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for these three talented people have made a great, really a great... They just made a wonderful motion picture out of 'Zhivago' and they are certainly not to be [denied] this evening. Thank you.

name: Laszlo, Ernest
speeches.speech: ERNEST LASZLO: I had a wonderful journey on this ship. Thank you. I'm very grateful.

name: Stevens, Inger
speeches.speech: INGER STEVENS: On behalf of Mr. Young I want to thank the Academy for this wonderful honor. Thank you.

name: Stevens, Connie
Sommer, Elke
speeches.speech: ELKE SOMMER: I know how excited Miss Harris will be when she receives her Oscar. Not only is the Oscar one of the world's, or the motion picture world's... [Connie Stevens has also come up onstage and is standing in the background with presenter Lana Turner.] What's going on behind me? Both of us?  CONNIE STEVENS: [Laughing] Yes!  ELKE SOMMER: [Sommer brings Stevens up to the podium and holds up her notes:] Let's read it.  JAMES GARNER: In unison.  ELKE SOMMER & CONNIE STEVENS: I know how excited Miss Harris will be when she receives this.  ELKE SOMMER: [To Stevens: I'll read the next sentence; you the next one.] Not only is the Oscar one of the highest awards in the motion picture world, but it is one of the greatest honors in the world of fashion, since...  CONNIE STEVENS: ...much of the most exciting thinking in design is done by film people. Thank you very much.  ELKE SOMMER: Thank you in the name of Miss Julie Harris.

name: Grayson, Kathryn
speeches.speech: KATHRYN GRAYSON: On behalf of Miss Phyllis Dalton I would like to say thank you very much. Thank you.

name: Andrews, Julie
speeches.speech: JULIE ANDREWS: Oh, it gives me the greatest pleasure in the world to accept this for Robert Wise. I know he's heartbroken not to be here this evening. Unfortunately, he's busy filming in Hong Kong, but on his behalf thank you very, very much indeed.

name: Glazier, Sidney
speeches.speech: SIDNEY GLAZIER: Thank you very much. I'd like to just do an inadequate thank you to the twenty-seven countries of the world that supplied some of the material for the film. To Mimi Arsham, our film editor, who spent many a lonely night. To Ezra Laderman, who wrote a sensitive and beautiful score. But most of all, to one of America's outstanding poets and playwrights, who wrote an original screenplay that became the heartbeat and the discipline for 'The Eleanor Roosevelt Story,' Archibald MacLeish. Thank you very, very much.

name: Thompson, Francis
speeches.speech: FRANCIS THOMPSON: I thank the members of the Academy for the very great honor they've conferred upon us this evening. And I thank them in behalf of Alexander Hammid, my co-director; of Gene Forrell, who did the musical score; and of the whole group of people, the earnest filmmakers, who worked so hard to make this moment possible for us. I also want to say a special word of thanks to Mr. Herbert Johnson of Johnson's Wax, who commissioned the film and who gave us complete creative freedom during its production. I only hope that other filmmakers in our kind of work have as great an opportunity as we. Thank you very much.

name: Reynolds, William
speeches.speech: WILLIAM REYNOLDS: There's a secret to winning an Oscar for film editing and that is: When in doubt, cut to Julie Andrews. You can't lose. Thank you.

name: Kadar, Jan
speeches.speech: JAN KADAR: I am very, very happy and deeply moved. I should like to thanks all member of Academy, all voters of Academy, and all friends who have helped our film such a lot here in States. Uncle Oscar is the highest appreciation not only for us personally, but for all our cinematography. Thank you, and I am sorry for my English.

name: Jarre, Maurice
speeches.speech: MAURICE JARRE: Thank you very much. It's a good opportunity to me to say thank you, because it's a second time I get this big thing. And I would like to say to every member of the Academy thank you, but I don't forget my musicians [pointing down to the orchestra pit]. Thank you very much. And David Lean, because it's the second one also.

name: Kostal, Irwin
speeches.speech: IRWIN KOSTAL: My thanks go to Richard Rodgers' wonderful music, the great sound of Julie Andrews' voice, the musicians who played the glorious orchestral sounds, 20th Century-Fox Sound and Todd-AO Sound with Murray Spivack. And last of all, of course, Oscar and me thank everybody.

name: Mandel, Johnny
Webster, Paul Francis
speeches.speech: JOHNNY MANDEL: Well, Paul, you're a little better at this; you've been here...a couple of times.  PAUL FRANCIS WEBSTER: I just want to say I'm deeply honored and very proud. Thank you very much.  JOHNNY MANDEL: Well, this is probably the proudest moment I can remember. I'd like to thank everyone. I'd like to thank in particular Marty Ransohoff who gave me the job in the first place. Thank you.

name: Chaplin, Saul
speeches.speech: SAUL CHAPLIN: I'm proud to accept this in behalf of Robert Wise. I'm sure if he were here he would first want to thank the members of the Academy. He would also, I think, want to thank everybody connected with making the film. I can only say, as one of those members, I would like to thank him for making filmmaking such a rewarding and stimulating experience. Thank you very much.

name: Persell, Jerry
speeches.speech: JERRY PERSELL: For Claude Berri, who is in Paris, thank you.

name: Hynes, Fred
Corcoran, James P.
speeches.speech: FRED HYNES: I'd like to thank the Academy for this honor and also to thank Murray Spivack, Joe Kane and Jerry Alexander. Thank you.  JAMES P. CORCORAN: I'd like to thank the Academy. I also wish to thank all those at 20th Century-Fox Sound Department who made this award possible.

name: Brown, Tregoweth
speeches.speech: TREGOWETH BROWN: To the members of the Academy, thank you very much. To Blake Edwards and Rudi Fehr who gave me the assignment, thanks a lot. And to the team that worked with me to help me win the little boy. Good night and God bless you.

name: Tors, Ivan
speeches.speech: IVAN TORS: Thank you. I accept the award for John Stears with gratitude. In his name I would like to thank those who had assisted him, especially Jordan Klein, the underwater engineer, and the underwater team. Cubby Broccoli and Harry Saltzman, for giving them such a fine opportunity to do the fantastic. Thank you very much.

name: Lean, David
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: DAVID LEAN: I'm terribly, terribly pleased to be able to accept this for Robert. He had a most fiendishly difficult job and we wouldn't have got the brass to date but for him. Thank you very much.

name: Stevens, Connie
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: CONNIE STEVENS: Original screenplay writing, I think, is still the very foundation of the motion picture industry. On behalf of Mr. Raphael, thank you very much. I'm sure he's very honored.

name: DePatie, Edmond L.
speeches.speech: EDMOND L. DePATIE: This is unquestionably the proudest moment of my forty-two-year career in our industry, and especially so since Jean Hersholt and I worked as very close friends for many years. I thank the Board of Governors of the Academy very sincerely for voting me this distinguished honor. And a special, deep, heartfelt thanks to Jack Warner for his sympathetic understanding, consideration and interest in my many industry activities during the forty years of my close association with him and a very warm personal friendship. And finally, I want to thank the thousands and thousands of workers in this industry who may have helped me merit this award, if indeed I do merit it at all. Thank you very much.

name: Hope, Bob
speeches.speech: BOB HOPE: Thank you very much. Thank you. [To Jack Lemmon:] You knew about this? Thank you. Where's the cards? Thank you very much. This, [to Lemmon:] you couldn't tip me or anything, huh?  JACK LEMMON: Of course not.  BOB HOPE: Ladies and gentlemen, I'm caught with my idiot cards down. I wanna tell you I know that Julie Christie was all cracked up but I'm not a girl. I think I'll cry, too. No, [holding up the medal] that is a beautiful thing and it's got a little Oscar. [Showing it to Lemmon:] And how much do you think it'd cost to pump that kid up? Seriously, I appreciate this very much and I shall treasure this. Anybody that wants to look at this can come to my place; it'll be in the shrine. Thank you, all you members of the Academy. Thank you, Jack.  JACK LEMMON: You're welcome, Bob. Very well deserved.

name: Wyler, William
speeches.speech: WILLIAM WYLER: I knew Irving Thalberg when I first came to work at Universal many, many years ago. We were both very young, just kids, but there was a slight difference. I was an office boy and he was already general manager of the studio. Even then, and throughout his short but distinguished career, he insisted on quality in films, and good taste, and on sparing no amount of work and effort in order to achieve excellence. And for this reason I'm doubly proud and pleased to receive this award bearing both his name and mine, and most grateful to the Board of Governors of the Academy. Thank you very much.

name: Matthau, Walter
speeches.speech: WALTER MATTHAU: Thank you. The other day, as I was falling off my bicycle, I had the following thoughts: I was given a very juicy part; I was allowed to work with talented, exhilarating and beautiful people; I was given a good deal of money and a great deal of joy. And now, really, don't you think this is going a little too far? [Laughs.] Thank you, anyway.

name: Milton, Franklin E.
speeches.speech: FRANKLIN E. MILTON: I wish to thank the Academy on behalf of many people of our sound department whose technical talents and creative ability have made this possible. Thank you very much.

name: Wexler, Haskell
speeches.speech: HASKELL WEXLER: I hope we can use our art for peace and for love. Thanks.

name: Mohr, Hal
speeches.speech: HAL MOHR: I'm terribly sorry that I'm the wrong Moore; I spell my name differently than Ted. But I'd just like to say for him as I know he would like to say, that thank you for this terrific honor that you have bestowed upon him. I only wish that I could share it with him directly.

name: Bagnall, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE BAGNALL: Well, Jean Hersholt was a friend of mine, and he's a friend of all mankind. As the former president of the Motion Picture Relief Fund he left footprints that were deep enough to withstand the erosions of time and winds. I am gratified you think I've been able to follow him and I thank you sincerely for this treasured honor. But thank you even more for your continued support of our industry-sponsored welfare agencies. I have to add that I again thank the Academy and the industry with which I have been identified. Thank you very much.

name: Hubley, John
speeches.film: Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass Double Feature
speeches.speech: JOHN HUBLEY: Thank you all very much. And we'd like to thank Herb Alpert, Jerry Moss, Gil Friesen, all the great artists who worked on the film, and all the members of the Academy. I thank you.

name: Goldman, Michael
speeches.speech: MICHAEL GOLDMAN: On behalf of Edgar Anstey, thank you.

name: Daniel, Gordon
speeches.speech: GORDON DANIEL: Oh, it's just too much. Well, thank you very much to the Academy and the marvelous people I work with.

name: Persell, Jerry
speeches.speech: JERRY PERSELL: For Peter Watkins, I would like to express his thanks to the Academy and its members for their appreciation of his efforts. Thank you.

name: Levy, Edmond A.
speeches.speech: EDMOND A. LEVY: 'A Year toward Tomorrow' was made for VISTA, which many people know as the domestic Peace Corps. And I'd like to thank those VISTAs whose achievements in working with the poor were the basis for the film and the basis for this honor. Thank you.

name: Cruickshank, Art
speeches.speech: ART CRUICKSHANK: My thanks to the many talented technicians whose combined efforts made this picture possible. And I also want thank the man who should be here beside me, Mr. L. B. Abbott. Thank you, Academy.

name: Louise, Anita
speeches.speech: ANITA LOUISE: It is with great pride and great honor that I accept on behalf of Miss Irene Sharaff this marvelous award. I hope that I have attempted to say what I know that she would have said under the circumstances. Thank you.

name: Rose, Helen
speeches.speech: HELEN ROSE: On behalf of my two very talented colleagues from Britain, Elizabeth Haffenden and Joan Bridge, I'm very proud and privileged to accept this award for them. Thank you very much, members of the Academy.

name: Nichols, Mike
speeches.speech: MIKE NICHOLS: Sandy thanks you very much. I thank Sandy. It was nice to be up here.

name: Freeman, Y. Frank
speeches.speech: Y. FRANK FREEMAN: Thank you, Jack. It has been a great privilege, which I've enjoyed, to be a member of the motion picture industry. It has also been a great privilege to have served for many years on the board of the Academy and to have been associated with a group of men dedicated to the betterment and the advancement of this industry. There was never anything selfish in their motives. I want to express to them my heartfelt appreciation for this award.  And to you, Jack, I want to say that we are fortunate that you've joined us as president of the Motion Picture Producers Association and I feel highly honored that you were the one selected to give me this award. Thank you.

name: Berman, Henry
speeches.speech: HENRY BERMAN: We would like to thank you, the members of the Academy, the very talented technical people at MGM, and the greatest film editing staff ever assembled. Thank you.

name: Canutt, Yakima
speeches.speech: YAKIMA CANUTT: Thank you. I want to thank the Academy, not so much, not so much for what I have enjoyed doing all these years myself and hope to continue doing, but in the name of the all those stuntmen and women who kept defying busted bones, bashed-in heads to make pictures more real and reality more picturesque. They're a great gang and I am honored you chose me to honor them.  [To Charlton Heston:] Now, what do you say we saddle up and get some action going.

name: Sylbert, Richard
Hopkins, George James
speeches.speech: RICHARD SYLBERT: Thank you very much. There are always a great many people to thank in the making of a film and I do thank them all. I'd like to thank a young director whose first picture it was my good fortune to work with him on, and that's Mike Nichols. Thank you.  GEORGE JAMES HOPKINS: I also have to thank Ernest Lehman for his many kindnesses.

name: Smith, Jack Martin
Hennesy, Dale
speeches.speech: JACK MARTIN SMITH: I have an idea the four of us look more like a polo team cause there's just four. Believe me, we -- all four of us -- have a lot to thank tomorrow when we go back to the studio, a whole lot full of people who helped make this picture possible. Thank you so much.  DALE HENNESY: A very special thanks to Frank Armitage, Tom Greaves*, Art Cruickshank and Ernie Laszlo. Thank you very much.

name: Bolt, Robert
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: ROBERT BOLT: Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen. You really are incredibly generous to aliens. You've been so generous to me that I think the time has come for me to reveal the secret of my success in this field. And my advice to any aspiring young writer for the film medium is very simple: Just make sure that you write for either David Lean or Freddy Zinnemann.  I've also got a couple of metaphorical Oscars of my own which I want to bestow. One to Bill Graf, our executive producer, who brought Freddy and myself together and suggested that we have a go at it. And the other one to Johnny Box, who on a pretty small budget created the mock-ups of various palaces and castles, inside and out, which were so good that I, I think in common with a lot of other people, when I first saw them on the rushes, thought they were the real thing. Thank you very much. I'm very proud to have this.

name: Wise, Robert
speeches.speech: ROBERT WISE: To those writers, actors, cameramen, editors, craftsmen on the stages and the back lots and distant location sites. To the executives and all who make pictures possible and to the audiences who respond. Let me respond with a sincere and most grateful thank you.

name: Radin, Paul
speeches.speech: PAUL RADIN: The producers of 'Born Free' join you of the Academy in paying honor to John Barry, a fine composer. And he in turn has asked me to say thank you.

name: Black, Don
speeches.film: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum
speeches.speech: DON BLACK: On behalf of Ken Thorne I'd like to say thank you very much to all the members of the Academy. Thank you.

name: Black, Don
speeches.speech: DON BLACK: On behalf of John Barry I'd just like to thank Mr. Carl Foreman and Donnie Kirshner and all the members of the Academy. Thank you very much.

name: Zinnemann, Fred
speeches.speech: FRED ZINNEMANN: Ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of all the people who worked on 'Man for All Seasons,' especially Robert Bolt, John Box and Bill Graf, I would like to thank you for this great honor. I must also thank the Columbia executives, and especially Mike Frankovich, for the courage, enthusiasm and faith they had in this project. Thank you.

name: Hiller, Wendy
speeches.speech: WENDY HILLER: It is a great joy to me to accept this award on behalf of one of the finest and one of the most loved actors in my country. There is something very special in being recognized in a country other than one's own and I know that Paul Scofield would want me to say with great warmth and great humility, thank you.

name: Bancroft, Anne
speeches.speech: ANNE BANCROFT: Miss Taylor regrets very much that she can't be here tonight. I'm sure she must be very, very proud; not half as nervous as me, I'm sure. But she thanks you very, very much. Thank you.

name: Zinnemann, Fred
speeches.speech: FRED ZINNEMANN: Thank you very much.

name: Lelouch, Claude
speeches.speech: CLAUDE LELOUCH: Thank you. Thank you very much. I'm sorry, I don't speak English. But 'Un homme et une femme' est un film d'amour; il a eu beaucoup de succès dans votre pays. Je voudrais maintenant qu'il y a pleine de metteurs-en-scène qui fassent des films pour que s'écoute les guerres du monde. Merci. Thank you very much.

name: Lelouch, Claude
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: CLAUDE LELOUCH: Thank you very much. Je voudrais avoir une pensée pour mon co-scènariste, Pierre Uytterhoeven, que mérite le prix autant que moi ce soir. Merci.

name: Hitchcock, Alfred
speeches.speech: ALFRED HITCHCOCK: Thank you.

name: Nichols, Mike
speeches.speech: MIKE NICHOLS: Until this moment my greatest pleasure in 'The Graduate' was making it, because it's a picture made by a group. And we cared for each other and we cared for what we were doing. So this award quite literally belongs to them at least as much as it does to me. I'm grateful to them and to the Academy and to the movies themselves. And I'd also like to wish my mother a happy birthday. Thank you.

name: Silliphant, Stirling
speeches.film: In the Heat of the Night
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: STIRLING SILLIPHANT: I really have no speech; the Writers Guild doesn't permit us to do any speculative writing. I'm deeply grateful and very touched. Thank you, Rod, Norman, Walter, Sidney, everyone. Thank you.

name: Newman, Alfred
Darby, Ken
speeches.speech: ALFRED NEWMAN: I can't say very much, but we're highly honored and very grateful indeed. Thank you.  KEN DARBY: The honor of winning this award can only be exceeded by the honor of working with Alfred Newman. Thank you all.

name: Davis, Sammy, Jr.
speeches.speech: SAMMY DAVIS, JR.: Leslie and Evie and the littlest Bricusses of all, they're busy working now. But I know that Leslie would want me to thank the members of the Academy for the honor. And, if I may, to say Leslie would probably say: [in a British accent] 'It's absolutely marvelous. It's super.' Thank you. God bless.

name: Kramer, Stanley
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: STANLEY KRAMER: Mr. Rose has been many times honored. I think if he were able to be here tonight he would say this is most certainly his greatest. Thank you.

name: Steiger, Rod
speeches.film: In the Heat of the Night
speeches.speech: ROD STEIGER: Thank you. Thank you very much. For maharishi's sake. Thank you, thank you, thank you.  Ladies and gentlemen, I thank you. I find it unbelievable, I find it overwhelming and I wish to thank the members of the Academy for such an experience. Secondly, if I may indulge myself, I would like to thank the people in the public who've been so kind to me. Thirdly, I'd like to thank Norman Jewison for his giving an actor freedom to make a mistake. Fourthly, and most importantly, I'd like to thank Mr. Sidney Poitier for the pleasure of his friendship which gave me the knowledge and understanding of prejudice in order to enhance my performance. Thank you, and we shall overcome.

name: Cukor, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE CUKOR: I know that I as her friend have a great, great thrill and I'm sure Katharine thanks you very much. And I think it's a very, very hard choice you had to make. Anyway, I'm sure she'll be very happy. Thank you very much.

name: Mirisch, Walter
speeches.film: In the Heat of the Night
speeches.speech: WALTER MIRISCH: Thank you, and thank you, members of the Academy. From its very inception 'In the Heat of the Night' has been a labor of love for all those of us who've been part of it. And I want to express my deep gratitude to all of the talented artists who contributed to it, but most particularly to my friend and partner Norman Jewison, whose brilliant direction brought it so vividly to life. We are all very grateful for your recognition of our efforts and for your recognition of the lesson of 'In the Heat of the Night.' Thank you.

name: Sawyer, Gordon E.
speeches.film: In the Heat of the Night
speeches.speech: GORDON E. SAWYER: I wish to thank the Academy members on behalf of the Samuel Goldwyn Sound Department. And I particularly would like to thank the boys that worked on this thing, especially Walter Goss, the production mixer, and Clem Portman, our re-recording mixer. Thank you very much.

name: Kennedy, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE KENNEDY: Oh, I could bust. I have to thank Stuart Rosenberg for giving me the opportunity to even be here. And I must simply thank the Academy for the greatest moment of my life. Thank you.

name: Guffey, Burnett
speeches.speech: BURNETT GUFFEY: Thanks everybody that helped me do it. That's all I can say.

name: Chapman, Christopher
speeches.speech: CHRISTOPHER CHAPMAN: Wow. Well, on behalf of the Ontario government, and David Mackay of T.D.F., and Barry Gordon, and the very many people who have made this film so successful, I thank you very, very, very much indeed.

name: Wolf, Fred
speeches.speech: FRED WOLF: Thank you, Shelly. Shelly Manne, musician who did this. Rich Harrison. My son Billy Wolf. My partner and I are very happy. Academy, thank you. Thank you very much.

name: Schoendoerffer, Pierre
speeches.speech: PIERRE SCHOENDOERFFER: I will thank you very much, the Academy. And I think that if my picture have any qualities, it's mostly due to the human quality of the thirty-three men of the platoon. And above all, because of the human quality of its leader, the Lieutenant Joe B. Anderson. So I'm very proud to share this honor with them.

name: Greenwood, Trevor
speeches.speech: TREVOR GREENWOOD: On behalf of King Screen Productions, Mark Harris the co-producer, and Dick Chew the photographer, we would like to extend our very sincere thanks to the Academy for this honor. Thank you very much.

name: Truscott, John
speeches.speech: JOHN TRUSCOTT: I really didn't expect this at all so I don't quite know what to say. So might I just say a simple thank you.

name: Freed, Arthur
speeches.speech: ARTHUR FREED: Thank you, Bob. I could never write a lyric that would properly express my gratitude. But reverting back to my job, keep the show moving, will you?

name: Abbott, L. B.
speeches.speech: L. B. ABBOTT: I want to most sincerely thank all the wonderful people that made this possible.

name: Olson, Keith
speeches.speech: KEITH OLSON: John is very sorry that he was not able to be here tonight but he asked me to thank all the members of the Academy for this wonderful Oscar. And a special thanks to Mr. Robert Aldrich and everybody at MGM for all the help. Thank you.

name: Bernstein, Elmer
speeches.speech: ELMER BERNSTEIN: My dear friend Bobby Helfer just conducted the orchestra to play me on, and if he hadn't encouraged me in 1954 when he was my agent, I wouldn't be here tonight. Thank you.

name: Parsons, Estelle
speeches.speech: ESTELLE PARSONS: Boy, it's heavy! I have to thank David Merrick who let me out of my Broadway play 'The Seven Descents of Myrtle' so I could be here this evening, and little did he know what it would really mean to me. I also first want to express my great gratitude to Arthur Penn, my own particular genius, for really showing me acting was something very special. And, of course, to Warren Beatty. And thank you all. This is a great moment.

name: Ashby, Hal
speeches.film: In the Heat of the Night
speeches.speech: HAL ASHBY: To repeat the words of a very dear friend of mine last year when he picked up his Oscar: I only hope that we can use all of our talents and creativity towards peace and love. Thank you.

name: Peck, Gregory
speeches.speech: GREGORY PECK: Thank you, Roz, and Governors of the Academy. It's a humbling experience to hear oneself described as a humanitarian at any time, but especially this week. I'll try to be deserving and, if I may, I would suggest that those of us who would like to help the humanitarian efforts of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference with its non-violent approach to our most pressing problems may do so by sending contributions – large or small – to the Martin Luther King, Jr. fund, Atlanta, Georgia. Thank you very much.

name: Menzel, Jiri
speeches.speech: JIRI MENZEL: I am very happy that Americans like Czech film. Thank you.

name: Truscott, John
Brown, John W.
speeches.speech: JOHN TRUSCOTT: Unfortunately, Mr. Carrere isn't here tonight. He's making a picture in Mexico. So on his behalf I would like to say thank you. And for myself, thank you again.  JOHN W. BROWN: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen of the Academy, for honoring me with this award. And I would also like to thank the technicians and craftsmen at Warner Bros.-Seven Arts Studios whose artistic achievements and excellent workmanship enabled me to get this honor. Thank you.

name: Gordon, Ruth
speeches.speech: RUTH GORDON: I can't tell you how encouragin' a thing like this is. The first film that I was ever in was in 1915 and here we are and it's 1969. Actually, I don't know why it took me so long; though I don't think, you know, that I'm backward. Anyway. Thank you, Bill. Thank you, Bob. Thank you, Roman. And thank you, Mia. And thank all of you who voted for me. And all of you who didn't, please excuse me.

speeches.name: N/A
speeches.speech: [Winner not present.]

name: Brooks, Mel
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Story and Screenplay--written directly for the screen)
speeches.speech: MEL BROOKS: I didn't trust myself in case I won so I wrote a couple of things here. I want to thank the Academy of Arts, Sciences and Money for this wonderful award. Well, I'll just say what's in my heart: Ba-bump, ba-bump, ba-bump, ba-bump. But seriously, I'd like to thank Sidney Glazier, the producer of 'The Producers,' for producing 'The Producers.' Joseph E. Levine and his wife Rosalie for distributing the film. I'd also like to thank Zero Mostel. I'd also like to thank Gene Wilder. I'd also like to thank Gene Wilder. I'd also like to thank Gene Wilder. Thank you very much.

name: Chambers, John
speeches.speech: JOHN CHAMBERS: [The Oscar statuette is brought on stage by a chimp wearing a tuxedo.] How can I follow an act like that?  May I thank the Board of Governors for this wonderful honor. And may I thank Mr. Zanuck, Mr. Jacobs, and Ben Nye and Dan Striepeke who share this award with me I say. But most of all, all those wonderful makeup men and hairstylists that worked so hard to make this picture a success. From all of us to all of you, God bless you and thank you so much.

name: Albertson, Jack
speeches.speech: JACK ALBERTSON: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen of the Academy. I didn't think I was gonna be this moved. I must say I'm glad I'm off the hook; it's the first one. And it's not the first time I've been an opening act.  There are so many people to thank I really don't know where to begin. I'd like to thank Edgar Lansbury, Ulu Grosbard, Martin Sheen. Of course that wonderful, wonderful actress and great woman, Patricia Neal. And throughout the years I've had the help and encouragement of many people and to them I'm extremely grateful, but I must say that my eternal gratitude will always be reserved for the man who made this moment possible: Frank Gilroy, the author of 'The Subject Was Roses.' Thank you very much.

name: Box, John
speeches.speech: JOHN BOX: Thank you very, very much. It's a great, great honor. Thank you.

speeches.name: N/A
speeches.speech: [No speech.]

name: Bass, Saul
speeches.speech: SAUL BASS: Thank you. Thank you very much.

speeches.name: N/A
speeches.speech: [Winner not present.]

speeches.name: N/A
speeches.speech: [No representative present.]

name: De Santis, Pasqualino
speeches.speech: PASQUALINO DE SANTIS: Grazie. Grazie a tutti.

name: Palmquist, Philip V.
speeches.categoryIndex: Scientific and Technical (Academy Award of Merit)
speeches.speech: PHILIP V. PALMQUIST: From all of us, thank you very much.

name: Savelyeva, Ludmila
speeches.speech: LUDMILA SAVELYEVA: [Makes a statement in Russian.] Thank you very much. I love you.

name: Green, Johnny
speeches.categoryExact: Music (Score of a Musical Picture--original or adaptation)
speeches.speech: JOHN GREEN: Thank you, ladies and gentleman. Gosh, to get one of these from Mancini; what an honor. I must express my thanks, ladies and gentleman, first of all, first of all to Lionel Bart for those wonderful songs. To John Woolf, Carol Reed, Onna White and John Box. To my associate Eric Rogers and all those fabulous British colleagues. To my American music editor Ken Runyon and his British associate Bob Hathaway. And before I leave this stage I must say, express my great gratitude to two executives of Columbia Pictures but for whom I wouldn't have been there in the first place: Mike Frankovich and Jonie Taps. God bless you. Thank you.

name: Goldman, James
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: JAMES GOLDMAN: I've been told by people who have been through this experience that the smiles of joy that appear occasionally up here don't come from joy at all but sheer relief. And it's absolutely true and I can't tell you how relieved I am.

name: Sinatra, Frank
Robertson, Cliff
speeches.speech: FRANK SINATRA: Ladies and gentleman, Mr. Robertson is filming in the Philippines and unfortunately he is steeped in it, couldn't get away in time. But on his behalf, he thanks the Academy, and I wish him the joyous moment of his life right now. Thank you.

name: Guggenheim, Charles
speeches.speech: CHARLES GUGGENHEIM: This award belongs in small part to those of us who produced this picture. It belonged rather in honor of the life of the man for whom the picture was produced about. Tonight you have given honor to Robert Kennedy.

name: Reitherman, Wolfgang
speeches.film: Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day
speeches.speech: WOLFGANG REITHERMAN: To us who have worked with Walt this is a very special Oscar and it's a memorable moment in all of the moments we've all shared with Walt. Thank you.

name: White, Onna
speeches.speech: ONNA WHITE: [Mark Lester brings the Oscar statuette on stage and hands it to Onna White.] You all recognize the young man who plays 'Oliver' in our film, Mark Lester. Thank you.  There's a first time for everything and this is my first time tonight. On Broadway I've had seven nominations and never won, and what a marvelous way to win one with this special. I want to thank everyone in the Academy and everyone concerned with 'Oliver!' I'd like to mention each one but I'm afraid I'll forget somebody so I'll just thank them all collectively. However, we all want to make special mention of the gentleman who collected and guided us through the whole thing: Mike Frankovich. I would like also to thank my assistant Tom Panko, who did a great deal and helped me a lot. Thank you very much. And thank the Academy again.

name: Keller, Frank P.
speeches.speech: FRANK P. KELLER: Thank you all very much. And my special thanks to our director Peter Yates and all the other talented people that made 'Bullitt.'

name: Bergman, Alan
Bergman, Marilyn
speeches.speech: MARILYN BERGMAN: Oh, it's heavy. Well, we've got them in stereo. Thank you.  ALAN BERGMAN: Thank you. We'd like to thank first of all Michel Legrand for that beautiful melody. And to Norman Jewison for the wonderful piece of film that we wrote it. And to, well, to you all. Thank you very much.  MARILYN BERGMAN: Thank you.

name: Reed, Carol
speeches.speech: CAROL REED: Not having made a musical before you can imagine what I owe to other people. There's Onna White and of course Lionel Bart and Johnny Green, but so many others that have helped me throughout it. But I would like to just make a special mention for our producer, John Woolf. And on behalf of all of them, I would just like to say how very proud and honored I am that you've given me your Oscar tonight. Thank you.

speeches.name: N/A
speeches.categoryExact: Music (Original Score--for a motion picture [not a musical])
speeches.speech: [Winner not present.]

name: Raye, Martha
speeches.speech: BOB HOPE: Martha, I know that you probably don't realize you're the first woman to ever receive the Jean Hersholt Award.  MARTHA RAYE: Yes, sir, I do realize it. I do realize it. [To Bob Hope:] I'm so nervous...  BOB HOPE: I know, but you're on.  MARTHA RAYE: [To Bob Hope:] Oh, I'm sorry...  Academy, ladies and gentlemen, my dear, beautiful legend Bob Hope. This is the most beautiful, honorable, wonderful, exciting day of my life – stateside. And on behalf of all of our troops, myself, I promise you I shall try for the rest of my life to really deserve and be worthy of this magnificent honor bestowed upon me. God bless you and thank you.

name: Harvey, Anthony
speeches.speech: ANTHONY HARVEY: When I asked Miss Hepburn what she thought when she had broken the records for winning the, breaking the records for nominations, she said, 'I suppose if I have lived as long as I have, anything can happen.' And I'm absolutely thrilled that it has happened. Thank you very much.

name: Streisand, Barbra
speeches.speech: BARBRA STREISAND: [To the Oscar:] Hello, gorgeous.  And I'm very honored to be in such magnificent company as Katharine Hepburn. And gee whiz, it's kind of a wild feeling. Sitting there tonight I was thinking that the first script of 'Funny Girl' was written when I was only eleven years old, and thank God it took so long to get it right, you know. So I would like to thank my co-producer Ray Stark for waiting till I grew up. And Jule Styne and Bob Merrill, for giving me such a great score to sing. And Isobel Lennart, for writing such a terrific character. And all the Hollywood people who made our show into a movie: Herb Ross, and my dear Harry Stradling who I haven't let go since, and my dear friend and director, William Wyler. Wow. It's like, somebody once said to me, asked me, if I was happy. And I said, 'Are you kidding? I'd be miserable if I was happy.' And I'd like to thank all the members of the Academy for making me really miserable. Thank you.

name: Woolf, John
speeches.speech: JOHN WOOLF: I'm very privileged to be here this evening representing the team that made 'Oliver!' I'm deeply grateful to you all. And I particularly and very sincerely want to thank our very great director Sir Carol Reed; Lionel Bart, without whom we'd have had no film at all; and all my British and American colleagues who made tonight possible. Thank you very much.

name: Wayne, John
speeches.speech: JOHN WAYNE: Wow! If I'd have known that I would have put that patch on thirty-five years earlier. Ladies and gentlemen, I'm no stranger to this podium. I've come up here and picked up these beautiful golden men before, but always for friends. One night I picked up two: one for Admiral John Ford, one for our beloved Gary Cooper. I was very clever and witty that night, the envy of even Bob Hope, but tonight I don't feel very clever or very witty. I feel very grateful, very humble, and all thanks to many, many people. I want to thank the members of the Academy. To all you people who are watching on television, thank you for taking such a warm interest in our glorious industry. Good night.

name: Newman, Lionel
speeches.categoryExact: Music (Score of a Musical Picture--original or adaptation)
speeches.speech: LIONEL NEWMAN: Lennie Hayton couldn't make it tonight but I'm sure he's just as gassed as I am. I do want to take this moment to thank Dick Zanuck, not only for this but for everything he's done for me; and for Ernie Lehman for being so goddamn beautifully difficult. And for the sound and the wonderful orchestra at Fox – I don't know what the hell I'm saying, but thank you very much.

name: Bacharach, Burt
speeches.film: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid
speeches.categoryExact: Music (Original Score--for a motion picture [not a musical])
speeches.speech: BURT BACHARACH: I'm deeply happy, I just can tell you that. It was a knock-out picture to work on. And I'm very thrilled. It's a great night. Thank you!

name: Bacharach, Burt
David, Hal
speeches.film: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid
speeches.speech: HAL DAVID: This is just marvelous. I'm deeply honored. Thank you so much.  BURT BACHARACH: I feel the same way and it's so special. Two of them. I mean, just, it's too fantastic. Very special to me, tomorrow morning they'll be on the breakfast table of our daughter. She's only, not even four years old, but I swear she'll look at these two and she'll know how very special they are. You made me very, very happy. I thank you. All my heart.

name: Solomon, Jack
Spivack, Murray
speeches.speech: MURRAY SPIVACK: I wish to thank the members of the Academy, Mr. Ernest Lehman, Mr. Gene Kelly. And especially the members of the 20th Century-Fox sound department who worked with me on 'Hello, Dolly!,' namely Mr. James Corcoran, Douglas Williams, Vinton Vernon, Ted Soderberg, Edward Thirlwell and Jack Solomon. I'm very grateful.  JACK SOLOMON: Thank everybody.

name: Stern, Joan Keller
speeches.speech: JOAN KELLER STERN: When I decided to submit 'Magic Machines' to the Academy, I was warned by my friends who are very kind that it touched on some things that were controversial and that it was really something from another generation. But the fact that it's touched you and that you've chosen to honor it in this way means that there can't be such a big gap between us after all. I thank you.

name: Kimball, Ward
speeches.film: It's Tough to Be a Bird
speeches.speech: WARD KIMBALL: I want to thank all the wonderful talent out at Disney Studios who helped make this possible. And I want to thank all of the bird lovers and bird watchers in the Academy. I also want to extend my condolences to the unfortunate seagulls in Santa Barbara. Thank you.

name: Hall, Conrad L.
speeches.film: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid
speeches.speech: CONRAD HALL: I'd like to thank Katharine; she wanted me to have it. And all of you, too.

name: Bonnot, Françoise
speeches.speech: FRANÇOISE BONNOT: Well I don't know how to, what to say. Just thank you. And I would like to thank Costa-Gavras who gave me the chance to do it.

name: Robertson, Robbie
speeches.speech: ROBBIE ROBERTSON: Thank you, Academy members, Mr. Frankovich, John Sturges and all the men that helped me on this picture. Thank you.

name: Jessel, George
speeches.speech: GEORGE JESSEL: I came out a little too soon. I was listening though just now and for a minute I thought I was dead. But this is the closest I've been to an Academy [Award] since I carried Zanuck's coat for 'Gentlemen's Agreement' years ago. But I'm very, very grateful. At my time of life one is grateful not only for this reward of the Oscar but also for a broken umbrella. I'll take anything that's going on. I want to thank the Hersholt family, the Academy, and you, sir [presenter Bob Hope]. And I've waited a long time but it shows that God's delay does not mean God's denial. Thank you so much.

name: Reichenbach, François
Rubinstein, Arthur (Mrs.)
speeches.film: Arthur Rubinstein - The Love of Life
speeches.speech: FRANÇOIS REICHENBACH: Thank you. Because of this film I think I met the most wonderful man on earth – music, love, and everything he has. [To Mrs. Rubinstein:] Thank you, madame, for him.  MRS. ARTHUR RUBINSTEIN: Thank you. Well, I must say that I am terribly moved. I'm happy that we convinced my husband to do that picture because he really wasn't, he was shy about it. He didn't want to do it. I'm very moved because people selected, and the Academy selected it. And that everybody voted, I mean the friends voted, those who liked it. And then I'm also very moved by being in this hall where my husband usually plays. And that he should receive this award, I mean here the producer, it's very moving too. And I'm sorry he's not here.

name: Sanders, Denis
Fresco, Robert M.
speeches.speech: ROBERT M. FRESCO: I think we should tell you that this film is about freedom, and perhaps we should share this with the motion picture industry of Czechoslovakia which filmed much of what is in our film and made it available to us.  DENIS SANDERS: I think we're feeling very, very successful tonight and I think we should, I'm sure we share that sense of well-being with our brilliant editor Marvin Walowitz and our remarkable composer Chuck Bernstein.  ROBERT M. FRESCO: Thank you.

name: DeCuir, John
Smith, Jack Martin
speeches.speech: JOHN DeCUIR: For the group I would like to say thanks first to the Academy, to our great producer Mr. Ernest Lehman, our director Gene Kelly, and the man that made it all possible, Mr. Richard Zanuck.  JACK MARTIN SMITH: Members of the Academy, we want to salute the hundreds of people who had much to do with making the sets on 'Hello, Dolly!' come true. Thank you so much.

name: Bergen, Candice
speeches.speech: CANDICE BERGEN: Miss Furse is in England working on the film production of 'Scrooge' and I've been asked to accept this award for Maggie and to extend her sincere thanks to all. Thank you.

name: Grant, Cary
speeches.speech: CARY GRANT: I think you're applauding my stamina. [Banters with presenter Frank Sinatra.]  I'm very grateful to the Academy's Board of Directors for this happy tribute and to Frank for coming here especially to give it to me. And well, to all the fellows who worked so hard in finding those and assembling those film clips.  You know, I may never look at this without remembering the quiet patience of the directors who were so kind to me, who were kind enough to put up with me more than once, some of them even three or four times. There was Howard Hawks, Hitchcock, the late Leo McCarey, George Stevens, George Cukor and Stanley Donen. And all the writers. There was Philip Barry, Dore Schary, Bob Sherwood, Ben Hecht, dear Clifford Odets, Sidney Sheldon, and more recently Stanley Shapiro and Peter Stone. Well, I trust they, and all the other directors, writers and producers and leading women, have all forgiven me what I didn't know.  I realize it's conventional and usual to praise one's fellow workers on these occasions, but why not?! Ours is a collaborative medium, we all need each other. That's how we exist. And what better opportunity is there to publicly express one's appreciation and admiration and affection for all those who contribute so much to each of our welfare. You know, I've never been a joiner or a member of any particular social set, but I've been privileged to be a part of Hollywood's most glorious era. And yet tonight, thinking of all the empty screens that are waiting to be filled with marvelous images and idealogies, points of view, whatever, and considering all the students who are studying film techniques in the universities throughout the world and the astonishing young talents that are coming up in our midst, I think there's an even more glorious era right around the corner.  So before I leave you, I want to thank you very much for signifying your approval with this. I shall cherish it until I die, because probably no greater honor can come to any man than the respect of his colleagues. Thank you. So long.

name: Perrin, Jacques
Rachedi, Hamed
speeches.speech: HAMED RACHEDI: Our thanks to all technician, all artist, all friends who make this Oscar possible. Thank you.  JACQUES PERRIN: We want thanks also especially our partners Mr. Schlumberger, Mr. Lagda* and Mr. d'Argila, and also the award because the movie is censored in very many country but with this award you help us. Thank you.

name: Young, Gig
speeches.speech: GIG YOUNG: Thank you, I'm really quite speechless. There are so many people to thank in the making of a picture. I thank the Academy. I thank the producers, Mr... Winkler – I hope I do better than that tonight. Mr. Winkler, Mr. Chartoff, Mr. Sills. Johnny Green, for his wonderful music. Our very talented director, Mr. Sydney Pollack. But in my heart I have a special thanks for a man whose friendship goes back many years with me, a man who always believed in me when things were not going well or going right. The man who gave me this part, my friend for many years, Mr. Martin Baum. Thank you, Marty. Thank all of you.

name: Welch, Raquel
speeches.speech: RAQUEL WELCH: Thank you. It's a pleasure to accept this award for her. She couldn't be here because she's in London filming. But I know she would want to thank all her co-stars, Walter Matthau and Ingrid Bergman, her director Gene Saks, and Mike Frankovich. And I think it's wonderful for her. Thank you.

name: Salt, Waldo
speeches.categoryExact: Writing (Screenplay--based on material from another medium)
speeches.speech: WALDO SALT: It's very exciting. I want to thank all the beautiful people who helped to make 'Midnight Cowboy.' Most of all I want to thank all the beautiful people who are going to see it. And may their number increase.

name: Ross, Katharine
